passages.text: Reiterate Rating: BUY | PO: 13,800 JPY | Price: 12,320 JPY

We raise our estimates, mainly on higher- than- expected volume growth in optical cable and connectors, and our price objective (PO). We use higher valuations in our PO calculation on the basis of enhanced growth potential, adopting a FY3/27E P/E of 23x (was 20x), which is equivalent to the upper end of historical range (5- 23x). Our Buy rating is based on our expectations for consensus- beating earnings resulting from high growth in optical cable and components for North American data centers, and expansion in electronic components for hard disk drives (HDD).

We raise our operating profit (OP) estimate from 165.0bn to 185.0bn for FY3/26 (consensus is 161.5bn), and from 204.0bn to 225.0bn for FY3/27 (14.7bn). We model 2Q OP of 47.9bn, ahead of 40.1bn consensus. We expect full- year OP guidance to be raised from 142bn to 160- 170bn, providing a positive share- price catalyst.

Fujikura benefits substantially from surging hyperscaler capex, owing to its elevated portfolio exposure to data center applications (70- 80% of total profit). In addition, we expect it to benefit from improvement in product mix in areas such as multiple cores in optical fibers, and smaller optical connectors. Given that completion of the company's next stage in optical fiber/SWR expansion is in 2028, we see risk around capacity constraints until then but we nonetheless forecast continued high profit growth.

Electric wire company that handles optical communications equipment/components such as optical connectors, optical cable and fusion splicers, components for PCs (electronic wires, membrane switches, HDD carriages), components for smartphones (flexible printed circuit boards, connectors), optical ground wire, wire harnesses, and real estate. Optical and electronic components are the main causes of earnings fluctuations. In real estate, Fujikura has an office and commercial facility in Kiba, Tokyo.

Our Buy rating is premised on our expectation of above- consensus earnings because of growth in demand for optical components and super multi- core cables related to data centers, and improved profitability in electronic components for the iPhone, and strengthening demand for low-/high- voltage electric wire as plants are expanded in Japan.

We model 2Q OP of 47.9bn, seeing further QoQ improvement earnings based on strong shipments of optical cable and connectors. We expect full- year OP guidance to be raised from 142bn to 160- 170bn, providing a positive share- price catalyst. Hyperscaler investment has become a key indicator for Fujikura earnings. We assume this investment sustains very high growth and Fujikura maintains profit growth from next FY onward (see our 8 August report "Q2 Cloud capex review"). Recently, Fujikura referred to optical connector capacity expansion of \(30\%\) and we therefore assume it can cater to surging demand. Given that optical connector expansion takes around six months, the focus shifts to the next round. The company disclosed optical fiber and SWR expansion plans in August. Startup is slated for 2028 and the company expects some external optical fiber sourcing until then.

The magnitude of hyperscaler investment is a key focus for the Fujikura share price. This investment has a volatile track record and correlates closely with company earnings. We therefore pay close attention to customers' AI server investment stance and monetization.

We see tougher competitive conditions ahead. Vibrant demand is fueling capacity expansion by competitors like Furukawa Electric, Sumitomo Electric, and Corning. That said, we see limited risk in this regard if demand remains strong given that Fujikura cannot meet all of current demand.

Capacity constraints are a focus. We are watching whether Fujikura can handle surging demand in optical fiber and SWR in particular, given extra capacity does not come on stream until 2028. The company is looking to improve productivity on SWR lines and expects some external sourcing in optical fibers. We need to watch whether it can source sufficiently from competitors (e.g. Furukawa Electric, Sumitomo Electric).

The main source of profit is the telecommunication systems segment, which primarily consists of optical components/cables and optical fusers/splitters. The electronics segment features a high sales ratio of components for the iPhone (connectors, flexible printed circuit boards). The company owns sizeable real estate in Kiba, Koto- ku, Tokyo that generates steady yearly operating profit of around \(\yen 5bn\) .
Exhibit 8: Fujikura (5803): OP breakdown by segment (FY3/2025) Main business is telecommunications systems; stable earnings in real estate

Telecommunication systems- This segment has four subsegments: optical cable systems, optical fiber, fusion machines and America Fujikura Limited (AFL). Demand is mainly related to data centers and optical communications infrastructure.- As of FY3/25, \(50\%\) of sales are to telecom carriers and \(50\%\) to data centers. In FY3/24, \(70 - 80\%\) of sales were to telecom carriers and \(20 - 30\%\) to data centers.- In FY3/25, \(82\%\) of sales were in the US. Data center customers are US hyperscalers like Amazon, Microsoft, Google and Meta. Customers for optical communications infrastructure vary from North American electric power companies to North American cable television (TV) providers, Verizon (major telecommunication carrier), companies that lease out optical cable networks, and CommScope.- About \(7\%\) of sales are to Europe. Customers include BT Group, CityFibre, the UK railways and the London Underground.- This business model is heavily exposed to yen depreciation because products manufactured in Japan are exported to the US and Europe.- Fujikura is known for its technological expertise. Even the company's president previously had responsibility for technological development. Fujikura developed its own manufacturing equipment and metal molds, not just for its optical fiber products, but also optical composite overhead ground wires (OPGW), and wrapping tube cable (WTC). It also utilizes artificial intelligence in testing. Technology may be the company's strength, but it seems likely that Fujikura is also savvy in its dealings with large blue- chip customers.
About \(70\%\) of this business is optical components, \(10\%\) optical cable, and \(20\%\) optical communications installations.

Products are mainly optical connectors, optical cables with optical connectors, optical cleaners and panels installed in optical termination cabinets. Cords and cables with connectors make up the bulk of sales. Cords and cables at plants are connected via optical connectors. Its product line is mostly geared toward data centers. Data centers account for roughly \(50\%\) . Demand is rising for multi- core optical connectors alongside increasing density of wiring within data centers.
Fujikura benefits from growth in the volume of optical connectors used as density increases for fiber due to higher data volumes within generative AI data centers.

Optical connector- based connections are rising as data centers become much larger in size, and as data centers switch to equipment consuming less electricity. In order to reduce energy consumption, products with minimal power losses are in high demand.
Optical connectors are becoming smaller as data centers become higher density and more power- efficient. The advantages of smaller connectors include the following:

1) Higher density: Smaller sizes allow more devices to fit in the same space, greatly increasing data center capacity.  
2) Power-saving: Smaller devices consume less power.  
3) Higher speed: Smaller sizes shorten the distance signals need to be transmitted, enabling faster data communication.  
4) Cost reductions: Improved space efficiency leads to lower capex and operational costs.  
5) Enhanced flexibility: The use of smaller devices allows greater flexibility in changing data center layouts and configurations.

Multi- fiber Push On (MPO) multi- core connectors are being superseded by slightly smaller Very Small Form Factor (VSFF) connectors. Fujikura produces a version of a VSFF connector, called a Multi- fiber Miniature (MMC) connector.
The MPO multi- core connector was developed by NTT.

MPO multi- core connectors are used for 800GbE (gigabit ethernet). As of FY3/25, the weighting of MMC multi- core connectors was only \(10\%\) . There is a limited number of suppliers for these connectors. MMC multi- conductor connectors use Tiny- Mechanically Transferable (MT) ferrules. US Conec granted Fujikura a patent license.
- MMC multi-core connectors are used in 1.6TbE (terabit ethernet) and 3.2TbE transceivers.- CPO (Co-packaged Optics) must use MMC connector, in our view.

In FY3/25, optical components that connect optical cables (SWR/WTC) to multi-core connectors have grown significantly. In addition to multi-core connectors, SWR (Spider Web Ribbon) and WTC (Wrapping Tube Cable) also have higher OPM than the average for the telecommunication systems segment.
- Furukawa Electric and Sumitomo Electric are competitors in products that connect optical cables to multi-core connectors.

In optical connectors, domestic subsidiary Fujikura High Opt manufactures connectors and ferrule (Ishioka factory in Ibaraki prefecture). In the US, US Conec (a joint venture with Corning and NTT Advanced Technology) produces connectors with ferrule supplied from Japan. Connectors are supplied to assembly plants.

- A ferrule is one of the components of an optical connector and refers to a terminal.- In Japan, in 3Q FY3/25, the company plans to expand production capacity for core component MT ferrule by roughly 2.4x the level in 4Q FY3/24. Capacity increased 3x YoY in all of FY3/25.- As of August 2025, the FY3/26 capacity expansion plan stands at 1.3x. This follows 3-fold expansion in FY3/25.- Capacity expansion does not require heavy investment and can be completed in about six months.- US-based US Conec makes a significant contribution to Fujikura's equity-method investment profit/loss.- Fujikura High Opt posted sales of ¥5,298mn (¥2,659mn in FY3/24), and NP of ¥2,045mn (¥729mn) in FY3/25. Operating profit margin in FY3/24 reached 43%.

- Capacity: Monterrey, Mexico is the location of its main plant for optical wiring components, managed by group company America Fujikura (AFL). AFL Poland aims to expand production capacity for optical wiring components with a new plant in Poland (about 300 workers). The company is investing to increase production capacity of MPO/MMC patch cords at its Vietnamese subsidiary Fujikura Fiber Optics Vietnam (FOV).

- Fujikura's optical connectors are sophisticated multi-core connectors (with 12-24 cores) for use in single-fiber mode, and its market share is 60-70% when including US Conec (a joint venture with Corning and NTT Advanced Technology). The main competitors are Corning (GLW US), Senko Advance, Furukawa Electric (Hakusan [5801 JP] is to
become a subsidiary), and Sumitomo Electric Industries (5802 JP). Other than Corning, Fujikura does not have any rival US connector makers in this field, other than Corning.

One of Fujikura's strengths is its high- precision manufacturing technology. Low loss transmission is a key requirement of optical connectors and Fujikura's processing technology meets this requirement. Its mold technology supports this.
Fujikura's market share of optical connector is high.
Optical cleaners are one of its major products.
Optical termination cabinets are one of its major products.
The main product is wrapping tube cable (WTC) with Spider Web Ribbon (SWR), an intermittent adhesive tape core. WTC is a super multi- core optical cable with bundles of optical fiber.
SWR is made entirely in Japan, and WTC is produced in Japan, by America Fujikura Limited (AFL), the US and Europe.

In 1H FY3/25, WTC products in the main have 1,728 cores. Ultra-high-core cables such as with 3,456, 6,912 and 13,824 cores are also on the market. This enables the manufacture of cables with approximately 7x the density of conventional products.
The price more than doubles when the number of cores is doubled, with commensurate improvement in product mix.
On 7 August 2025, Fujikura announced optical fiber and SWR capacity expansion targeted at rising demand for optical fiber and cable for data center internal connections and interconnection.
The plan calls for investment of around 45bn and construction at the Sakura plant.
SWR production capacity is to increase \(50\%\) after the expansion which completed in 2025.
Optical fiber capacity is to be expanded and optical fiber is targeted for a productivity increase of 2- 3x with the introduction of innovative manufacturing technology.
Startup is planned for FY29. Completion in 2028, aiming for full operation in 2029.
The approach to supply until expansion is completed is external sourcing in optical fiber, and productivity improvements on SWR lines.

Fujikura plans to invest almost 10bn to expand production capacity at Sakura Works, its primary base in Japan. Operations started in January 2025. The company raised SWR production capacity by roughly \(30\%\) of the volume produced in FY2022. The Sakura Works aim to become carbon neutral in the future. Starting in 2024, the company plans to produce SWR at its plant in South Carolina to comply with Build America, Buy America (BABA) Act.
Fujikura plans to procure US- made fiber from strategic partners and produce SWR/WTC products in compliance with the BABA Act.

Most of its customers for optical cables are in North America, where they are used by data centers and telecommunications carriers. Its next largest customer base is in Europe, where products are used by BT Group and railway operators.

Competitors: We can infer that Fujikura is the largest producer of super multi- core optical cables. Competitors include Corning, Leviton Manufacturing, Furukawa Electric, Hitachi Cable America, Belden (BDC US), Prysmian, and Optical Cable Corporation (OCC US).

Responses to co- packaged optics (CPO): Fujikura is experimenting with multi- core fibers and polarization- maintaining and absorption- reducing (PANDA) fibers. The company will be able to leverage its strengths in multi- core optical cable, high- precision technology, and high- precision optical connectors with CPO.
Exhibit 12: SwR (Spider Web Ribbon) and WTC (wrapping tube cable) Fujikura is the largest producer of super multi- core optical cables.
Optical communications installation

Fujikura installs optical communications gear in the US. The company offers services for FTTx, 5G and distributed antenna systems (DAS, for stadiums).  - This subsegment includes new business projects described below.

The dark fiber provider business in Canada where the company targets roughly 120bn in sales over five years. The dark fiber business may not have high margins, but the company anticipates stable profits. DAS- Local 5G business in the US (where it aspires to sales of 15bn or more in FY3/25 and a sales CAGR of over \(+10\%\) through FY28).
The company manufactures and sells optical fiber and preform, a base material for optical fiber, in Japan and China.

There are three methods for manufacturing optical fiber preforms: Vapor- phase Axial Deposition (VAD), Modified Chemical Vapor Deposition (MCVD), and Outside Vapor Deposition (OVD). Fujikura uses the VAD method. Fujikura uses \(90\%\) of the optical fiber it manufactures for its own optical cables. In China, Fujikura has an optical fiber base material joint venture with Fiberhome Telecom.
Competitors: The numerous competitors include Furukawa Electric, Sumitomo Electric Industries, Shin- Etus Chemical (4063 JP) and YOFC (6869 HK).
Fusion splicers are machines that connect optical fiber together.
Exhibit 13: Fujikura (5803): Sakura Works This is the SwR production plant, located in Chiba Prefecture.
BofA GLOBAL RESEARCH
- Optical cables can be up to 20km-long and requires splicing. There are two ways to connect cables: with connectors and fusion splicers. Fusion splicing uses arc welding.
- Demand mainly comes from telecommunications carriers.
- For data centers, workability is important, so multi-core fusion splicers are used. The number of fiber cores that can be spliced at once is typically 12 in the US and eight in Japan.
- Manufacturing: Parts are procured, assembled at the Kumamoto plant, and sold.

- Competitors: Fujikura has the top share of the world market. Competitors are mainly Sumitomo Electric Industries, Furukawa Electric and INNO Instrument (215790 KS). (53%, according to an INNO Instrument document), Competitors are mainly Sumitomo Electric Industries (24%), Furukawa Electric (6%), INNO Instrument (215790 KS; 5%), and Chinese companies.
Fujikura is a major manufacturer of optical fiber
Fujikura has the top share of the world market.
- AFL sells and installs optical fiber composite overhead ground wire (OPGW) and non-metallic self-supporting cables (ADSS cable) in North America.
- Customers are mainly power companies in North America.
These serve as both power transmission & optical communication lines
This segment consists of three subsegments: flexible printed circuit boards, connectors and other electronic components.

FPCs for smartphones make up around \(60\%\) of sales, and FPCs for tablets just over \(10\%\) . The remainder is mostly for digital cameras and automobiles.- Its key customer is the smartphone and tablet major in North America, and sales of FPCs are strongly influenced by production volumes at these customers.- The company is strong in FPCs for displays.- Fujikura's base in Thailand is a major producer of FPCs. It also has production sites in Vietnam, China, and Japan.- Competitors: NOK (7240 JP), Sumitomo Electric Industries, DSBJ (Suzhou Dongshan Precision Manufacturing, 002384 CH), Zhen Ding Tech (4958 TT), Flexium (6269 TT), Career Technology (6153 TT), Interflex (051370 KS) and BH (090460 KS).

Connectors, used to connect boards inside smartphones, make up \(70\%\) of sales. The rest are mainly for industrial equipment applications.- They are produced and sold in Japan, Thailand, Vietnam and China.- As with FPCs, customers are the North American smartphone major. Fujikura has a very high share of connector sales to these customers.- In FY3/24, sales decreased due to Europe requiring USB Type C cables for charging.

This business comprises electric wires (PC- related), hard disc drive (HDD) carriages, thermal parts for cooling PCs (heat sinks), pressure sensors (for production equipment), oxygen sensors (for medical equipment) and membrane switches (for touchpads).
Sales are relatively higher in electric wires and HDD carriages.

The HDD carriage market is an oligopoly of four companies, with the largest being Belton Totoku. Fujikura is the second or third largest, and other competitors are Broadway Industrial Group Limited (BWAY SP; Singapore) and JCY International (JCYH MK; Malaysia).
HDD carriage capacity is being increased in 2025.
In hard disc drive (HDD) carriages, the company is developing products compatible with heat- assisted magnetic recording (HAMR).
In thermal products, the company is developing multi- layer cold plates for liquid cooling used in generative AI applications, and aims to commercialize them by FY3/26.
Over 20 used in a smartphone
Mainly used in smartphones
One of the main components of HDDs

- Fujikura supplies automotive wire harnesses with operations in Europe, Asia and the Americas. In FY3/25, Europe contributed 36% to sales, North America 30%, Asia (including Japan) 23%, and others 11%.  
- Key customers: Volkswagen (Europe, China), Subaru (Japan, the Americas)  
- Competitors: Sumitomo Electric Industries, Yazaki, Furukawa Electric, Aptiv (APTV US), Lear (LEA US) and Leoni (LEO GR).  
- In FY3/24, in Asia, Fujikura shut down its Wuhu plant in China. In Europe, production was discontinued at its Comrat and Chisinau plants in Moldova.
This segment comprises Fujikura Dia Cable and Fujikura Energy Systems.
Fujikura Dia Cable (Fujikura stake \(70\%\) ) posted sales of \(101,059\mathrm{mn}\) and NP of \(5,308\mathrm{mn}\) in FY3/25.
The company produces and sells high- and low- voltage electric wires for industrial applications for the Japanese market.

A large number of urban redevelopment, semiconductor fab and data center construction projects in Japan are supporting strong demand. Mix improvement to high- value- added products is supporting stronger earnings.
Competitors: Sumiden HST Cable, SFCC and Yazaki Energy System
Exhibit 21: Industrial- use eco cablesHandles domestic high- voltage cable and medium- low voltage cable business
The company receives leasing revenue from Fukagawa Gatharia in Kiba, Koto- ku, Tokyo, which reliably generates around \(\) 5bn\$ in OP annually.
Business includes Tower N and S buildings, West 1, 2 and 3 buildings, Ito- Yokado and a Plaza building. Tenants include Resona Holdings and Nomura Research Institute.
According to the company's securities filings, the market value of its real estate holdings was \(114.1bn\) and the book value was \(38.8bn\) as of end- FY3/25.
Located in Koto- ku, Tokyo, next to Fujikura's headquarters. Generates annual OP of about ¥5bn
Fujikura's high- temperature superconducting wire is used in high- temperature superconducting magnets that generate strong magnetic fields.
The company makes rare earth superconducting wire using yttrium at its Sakura plant.
Many startups working on nuclear fusion power generation have emerged in the field of high- temperature superconducting wire, and demand for it is expanding.
Fujikura is supplying it to the US company Commonwealth Fusion Systems (CFS), UK Industrial Fusion Solutions Ltd (UKIFS), and Helical Fusion.
Demand for superconducting wire will increase dramatically, if nuclear fusion energy becomes a reality.
Fujikura plans to develop innovative manufacturing technologies and invest in production capacity expansion.
- The company is undertaking investment of ¥6bn from FY3/25, having secured a budget of ¥5.6bn in August 2025.
- Competitors: Competitors include Furukawa Electric (including SuperPower), Sumitomo Electric, and Supercon.
Each ¥1/\\$ depreciation increases annual OP by ¥1.7bn in FY3/2026

- The company's business model, where products manufactured in Japan are exported to the US, is highly exposed to forex fluctuations.- A large volume of products is also manufactured in Thailand, so earnings are likely influenced by the USD/THB exchange rate.
- Shareholder returns are based on a \(40\%\) dividend payout ratio.

Source: Company, BofA Global Research estimates
- The plan starts in FY3/24 and ends in FY3/26.

- The company is investing in three core areas: information storage; information infrastructure; and information terminals. It mainly invests in telecommunications, electronics, digital transformation (DX) and green transformation (GX) areas.
- Management aims for a capital-to-asset ratio of \(50\%\) .

Our PO of 13,800 is based on an FY3/27E P/E of 23.0x. This multiple is close to the upper limit of Fujikura's historical P/E range of 3- 23x. We use nearly the highest P/E of the historical range to reflect strong earnings growth, driven by optical multi- core connector volume growth on the back of increasing demand for artificial intelligence (AI) servers (for data centers).

Downside risks to our PO are (1) rapid yen appreciation (1 rise vs USD depresses annual OP by 1.7bn), (2) a sharp decline in optical communications demand, and (3) a swift slowdown in the smartphone and/or PC market.
Upside risks are (1) rapid yen depreciation, (2) sharp growth in optical communications demand, and (3) stronger- than- expected smartphone, PC market, and other IT- related demand.

Qmethod is the set of BoA Global Research standard measures that serve to maintain global consistency under three broad headings: Business Performance, Quality of Earnings, and validations. The key features of iQmethod are: A consistently structured, detailed, and transparent methodology. Guidelines to maximize the effectiveness of the comparative valuation process, and to identify some common pitfalls. Qatobase is our real- time global research database that is sourced directly from our equity analysts' earnings models and includes forecasted as well as historical data for income statements, balance sheets, and cash flow statements for companies covered by BoFA Global Research.
Qprofile, Qmethod are service marks of Bank of America Corporation. Qatobase is a registered service mark of Bank of America Corporation.

BofA Global Research personnel (including the analyst(s) responsible for this report) receive compensation based upon, among other factors, the overall profitability of Bank of America Corporation, including profits derived from investment banking. The analyst(s) responsible for this report may also receive compensation based upon, among other factors, the overall profitability of the Bank's sales and trading businesses relating to the class of securities or financial instruments for which such analyst is responsible.

From time to time research analysts conduct site visits of covered issuers. BofA Global Research policies prohibit research analysts from accepting payment or reimbursement for travel expenses from the issuer for such visits.
